The section on taking human life, the third section, the first of the four pÄrÄjika offenses, the continuation of the previous section. At that time, the Blessed One was in the country of Buddha-Likhita. The bhiká¹£us heard the Buddha speak of the contemplation of impurity. After cultivating it, they deeply felt disgust towards the body of pus and blood, and then sought out the non-Buddhist practitioners and Å›ramaá¹‡as to end their lives, and also killed each other.
In all cases of killing, it is due to the matter of intolerance and the afflictions of intolerance that one ends another's life. This training rule is established.

If there is a bhiká¹£u who, whether it is a human or a human embryo, intentionally with his own hands ends their life, or holds a knife for them, or holds a knife himself, or seeks someone to hold a knife, or encourages death, or praises death, saying:
'Alas, man!
What use is this sinful, impure, evil life?
You would be better off dead than alive.
' In accordance with their own thoughts, they use other words to encourage and praise them to die.
If the other person dies because of this, this bhiká¹£u also commits a pÄrÄjika offense and should not be allowed to stay [with the saá¹ƒgha].
This is committed due to the person as the object, having the intention to kill, the perception of a person, and the means of ending life.
Here, the object refers to a person or a human embryo.
A person means one who has the six sense faculties.
A human embryo means one who has entered the mother's womb and has the faculties of body, life, and mind, because this is included in the continuity of a human being.
The bodies of women, men, and paá¹‡á¸akas, whether complete or incomplete, are all objects of killing.
Intentionally means not mistakenly ending another's life.
The previous object is a person, and the mind and appearance match. There are two means:
namely, body and speech.
The body refers to using hands and so forth to commit murder;
or holding a knife and giving it to someone, knowing that the other person wants to kill themselves, and then placing a knife or other weapon nearby;
Or holding a knife oneself means oneself is powerless, but only holding a knife, allowing others to assist in killing;
or seeking others to hold a knife to kill.
Words means wishing to cause others to die, carrying out encouragement, praise, etc., for those who do not enjoy death, then encouraging them to die.
If one wishes for the dead, then praising them to die, saying:
What use is this sinful burden, etc.?
It is said:
The fault of remaining alive is heavy, but the merit after death is great.
Impure means relying on impurity to accomplish it.
Called impure evil living means it is abandoned by superior people.
Death is superior to life means wishing to bring joy to others.
According to one's own thoughts means encouraging others to die, which will bring merit.
With other words means not only speaking this, but also using other words to encourage and praise each other.
If he dies because of that shows that it is not due to other matters. Merely by encouraging death, causing another's life to be cut off, one attains pÄrÄjika.
If the other does not die, one attains sthÅ«lÄtyaya.
First giving rise to skillful means to send someone to kill another, later giving rise to regret and not wanting that person to die, even if the other person dies, one only attains sthÅ«lÄtyaya.
As for cutting off life and committing an offense, it means causing death because of that.

Here, the one who commits an offense is a bhiká¹£u who uses either his own body or an external brick, etc., or both together like holding a knife, etc., or using poison, or making a pitfall, or giving him wine and other medicines to make his mind confused, or performing a spell to send him into a daze, or making a trap, or pushing him off a cliff, tower, or dangerous place, or deceitfully setting up a means to send him into a frightening place of water, fire, or danger, or in the cold night leaving him out in the open to freeze.

If a man, woman, eunuch, or hermaphrodite has the thought that the other person is alive, or if they have doubts, and they create the means to harm, and because of this the other person dies, they all commit a pÄrÄjika offense.
If the other person does not die, they obtain a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense.
If they make a whole corpse or a half corpse rise up to harm the other person, the gravity of the offense should be understood according to the circumstances.
If there is a difference, if those two harm a bhiká¹£u in return, due to the previous means, they obtain a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense.
If a bhiká¹£u harms those corpse-ghouls, he obtains two coarse offenses.
If he harms a transformed form, he also obtains a coarse offense.
If he has no intention to harm the mother but has the intention to kill the fetus, and he treads on the mother's abdomen, if the fetus dies but not the mother, he commits a pÄrÄjika offense;
if the mother dies but not the fetus, he only obtains a coarse offense;
if both die, it is a pÄrÄjika offense;
if neither dies, it is a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense.
In this way, it should be understood that if he has the intention to kill the mother but not the fetus, it can be understood according to the previous cases.
If in the womb of a human woman there is an animal embryo or a non-human embryo, and one intentionally causes an abortion, one commits a coarse offense.
If in the womb of an animal one knows there is a human embryo, or if one knows a human has transformed into an animal, when one ends its life, one commits the fundamental offense.
If one transforms one's own body into the form of an animal and harms another person while having the perception of a bhiká¹£u, one also commits the fundamental offense.
If one wishes to harm another person but mistakenly harms one's parents or an arhat, one commits a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense.
Because one has no intention to kill one's father, etc.;
If one has the perception of an arhat but it is not an arhat, or one has the perception of an arhat but it is an arhat, the same applies to one's parents.
If one prepares to kill one's mother, etc., and they die in front of oneself, one commits a coarse offense.
If a woman's embryo is discarded and another woman picks it up and places it in her own womb, if one kills the later mother, one does not commit a heinous offense;
If one goes forth, one should ask the later mother.
If one has the perception of a human and kills, or if one has doubt, one commits the fundamental offense.
If one has the perception of a human but kills a non-human, one commits a coarse offense.
If one has the perception of an animal and kills, one commits an offense of wrong conduct.
If one has the perception of a non-human and kills, one also commits an offense of wrong conduct.
If a sentient being is being pursued and a bhiká¹£u sees it and tells others with the perception of killing, one commits an offense according to the circumstances.
If one has the intention to kill one person but mistakenly kills another, one commits a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense.
If one is in a neutral state of mind, one only commits an offense of wrong conduct.
If one strikes with the intention of joking and laughing, and the other dies because of it, one commits an offense of wrong conduct.
If one formulates a plan before receiving full ordination, and the other dies after full ordination, two sets of four alternatives should be formulated according to the previous method.
If one formulates a plan and sends someone to carry out the killing, and the other changes gender to become a nun, one still commits the fundamental offense.
If the other person develops both sexual organs, one commits the previous coarse offense.
If the other person regresses to become a novice monk, it is also the same coarse offense.
The other precepts should be understood according to the circumstances, and it is not necessary to explain them in detail.

If one sees sentient beings being carried away by water, burned by fire, or suffering from thirst, and does not rescue them with one's hands or give them water, or if one sees them about to die and has the ability to save them, or even if they do not wish to die but have a mind of indifference and do not save them, if they die, one commits an offense of wrong conduct.
If a person is killed by another, and for this reason their life definitely ends, the remaining life still commits a coarse offense;
If the death is uncertain, one commits a defeating offense.

If an urgent danger comes and one runs away with one's body, without compassion pushing against a person in front, without the intention to kill the person in front, and the person in front dies, one then commits a coarse offense;
If they do not die, it is wrong conduct;
If there is a killing mind, one commits a fundamental offense.
If one who has gone forth out of respect for the Dharma, who preserves life and seeks liberation, kills oneself, one commits a thullaccaya offense.

If one has no intention to kill at all, such as striking a wall and accidentally killing a person because of this method, or moving a patient against their wishes, or causing a patient to die while treating their illness, these are all not offenses.

If one has no intention to kill a patient, but what one says causes them to wish to die, or if one holds a knife or a rope and places it beside the patient without careful consideration, or places poison, one commits an offense of wrong conduct.
An ignorant person should not be allowed to care for the sick. If there is an urgent matter and one must attend to them, one should teach them well and make them fully attentive.
The patient says:
Do not help me get up.
If one forcefully helps them up and they die, one commits a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense.
One should understand the other deportments in the same way. If one is traveling and helps a sick person, one should understand this accordingly.
One tells the sick person:

Although this is not an offense, it is not appropriate to carry a seriously ill person away together and cause their death. There is no offense in this case, but one should not hastily carry them away.
Or the caregiver may become weary, or have evil intentions hoping for their wealth, or speak angrily:
Let you die, I cannot take care of you.
If this causes death, one commits a coarse offense.
If one gives inappropriate food to one who should be given appropriate food, the caregiver also commits a coarse offense;
if there is nothing else to be obtained, there is no offense.
If an unripe boil is pressed and the person dies, one commits a coarse offense;
if it is ripe, there is no offense.
It is not an offense to open it with a knife or a needle. One who is not skilled in medicine should not pierce it.
If one treats a mouth disease by piercing with a knife, it is a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense;
if there is no doctor to be found and one pierces it, there is no offense.
For those suffering from hemorrhoids, one should not cut them, but should use medicine and spells to alleviate them.
When treating illnesses, one should consult a doctor;
if there is no doctor, one should ask a monk who understands medicine;
if there is still no one, one should ask those who have had the illness before;
if there is no one who has had the illness before, one should ask the elders. If one gives medicine rashly, one commits a transgression of the precepts.
If a doctor comes to ask, one should give medical advice out of compassion, without seeking profit, and there is no offense;

If one sees a wound, one should wrap it in a secluded place, and not let laypeople see and ridicule the medical path.
When giving purgative medicine to others, one should not leave, but should teach what is appropriate. Leaving is not an offense.

When a monk is walking, if he lowers his head and kills someone in front of him without intention, it is not an offense.
You should not walk with your head down, with the intention of harming others. If you do, you commit a coarse offense. If you have the intention to kill, you commit a grave offense.

If you are worried it will be late, you should go ahead to the monastery, wash the bowl, set out the seat, and then request food to wait for the sick person. Or you can take the food and meet them on the road.

Do not give vinegar to an injured person to drink. If you see someone choking on food and you compassionately beat them and they die, there is no offense.

The fourth training rule on falsely claiming to have attained the superhuman qualities. The Buddha was at Vesali, on the bank of the Vaggumuda River. At that time, the monks, for the sake of food and drink, praised each other's attainment of the superhuman qualities in front of their relatives.
In order to make the assembly know and seek benefits and offerings, the matter and affliction of seeking benefits and offerings, this training rule was established.

If a monk, without true knowledge and complete understanding, knows for himself that he has not attained the noble, peaceful, and sublime realization of knowledge, vision, wisdom, and spiritual attainment, and yet says:
'I know, I see.
' At a later time, whether asked or not, in order to purify himself, he says:

Moreover, as for the ignorant, it means that they have never known the dharmas of superior people.
As for those without universal knowledge, it means that they are unable to thoroughly understand the dharmas of the five aggregates.
As for knowing oneself to be without attainment, it means knowing that one has not yet realized [the truth].
As for the dharmas of superior people, it refers to the supreme dharmas, which are superior to all the inferior and evil things such as the five hindrances of ordinary foolish people.
As for tranquility, it means the most wonderful.

The attainment of distinction is not due to physical strength or intelligence.

Knowledge and insight refers to the acceptance of the truth of suffering and the knowledge of the truth of suffering, respectively.
Another explanation says:

Abiding in bliss refers to being able to abide in the merits of various meditative states.
